quiz.title: Unit 12: AP Microeconomics (Quiz 9)
quiz.subtitle: True/False: Market Structures, Demand/Supply Principles, Equilibrium
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Perfect Competition, Laws of Demand/Supply, Equilibrium Effects

questions.question: A perfectly competitive market consists of products that are all slightly different from one another.
questions.explanation: Perfect competition requires homogeneous (identical) products, not differentiated ones.

questions.question: In a perfectly competitive market, each seller has a negligible impact on the market price.
questions.explanation: Perfectly competitive firms are price takers; no single seller can influence price.

questions.question: The law of demand states that an increase in the price of a good decreases the demand for that good.
questions.explanation: Law of demand states that an increase in price decreases quantity demanded (movement along the curve), not demand (shift of curve).

questions.question: If apples and oranges are substitutes, an increase in the price of apples will decrease the demand for oranges.
questions.explanation: Substitutes: price increase in one increases demand for the other.

questions.question: If golf clubs and golf balls are complements, an increase in the price of golf clubs will decrease the demand for golf balls.
questions.explanation: Complements: price increase in one decreases demand for the other.

questions.question: If consumers expect the price of shoes to rise, there will be an increase in the demand for shoes today.
questions.explanation: Expectations of higher future prices increase current demand (shift right).

questions.question: The law of supply states that an increase in the price of a good increases the quantity supplied of that good along its supply curve.
questions.explanation: Law of supply: higher price leads to higher quantity supplied, movement along supply curve.

questions.question: An increase in the price of steel will shift the supply of cars to the right.
questions.explanation: Higher input costs (steel) decrease supply of cars (shift left).

questions.question: When the price of a good is below the equilibrium price, it causes a surplus (i.e. an excess supply) of this good.
questions.explanation: Below equilibrium causes a shortage (excess demand), not surplus.

questions.question: The market supply curve is the horizontal summation of the individual supply curves.
questions.explanation: Market supply is the sum of quantities supplied by all firms at each price.

questions.question: If there is a shortage (i.e. an excess demand) of a good, then the price of that good tends to fall.
questions.explanation: Shortage creates upward pressure on price as buyers compete.

questions.question: If pencils and paper are complements, an increase in the price of pencils causes the demand for paper to decrease or shift to the left.
questions.explanation: Complements: price increase in one reduces demand for the other.

questions.question: If Coke and Pepsi are substitutes, an increase in the price of Coke will cause an increase in the equilibrium price and quantity in the market for Pepsi.
questions.explanation: Substitutes: higher Coke price increases demand for Pepsi, shifting demand right, raising price and quantity.

questions.question: An advance in the technology employed to manufacture roller blades will result in a decrease in the equilibrium price and an increase in the equilibrium quantity in the market for roller blades.
questions.explanation: Better technology increases supply (shift right), lowering price and raising quantity.

questions.question: If there is an increase in supply accompanied by a decrease in demand for coffee, then there will be a decrease in both the equilibrium price and quantity in the market for coffee.
questions.explanation: Increase in supply lowers price, decrease in demand lowers price. Price falls unambiguously, but quantity effect is ambiguous (depends on shift magnitudes).

questions.question: If a good is a normal good, then an increase in consumer income will decrease its demand.
questions.explanation: Normal good: demand increases when income rises. Inferior good demand decreases when income rises.

questions.question: In the long run, perfectly competitive firms earn zero economic profit.
questions.explanation: Free entry and exit drive economic profit to zero in the long run under perfect competition.

questions.question: A price ceiling set above the equilibrium price is binding and creates a shortage.
questions.explanation: A price ceiling above equilibrium is non-binding and has no effect. A binding ceiling is set below equilibrium.

questions.question: The marginal cost curve above the average variable cost curve is the perfectly competitive firm's short-run supply curve.
questions.explanation: In the short run, the firm's supply curve is the portion of MC above minimum AVC.

questions.question: If the cross-price elasticity of demand between two goods is positive, they are complements.
questions.explanation: Positive cross-price elasticity indicates substitutes. Complements have negative cross-price elasticity.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent grasp of microeconomic principles and logic.
scoreMessages.70: Solid understanding; review demand vs. quantity demanded, substitute/complement effects.
scoreMessages.50: Basic grasp; focus on perfect competition traits, supply/demand shifts, and equilibrium.
scoreMessages.0: Review: law of demand/supply, market structures, and simultaneous shift analysis.
